topic: Communications with Those Charged with Governance

questions.conceptTested: Definition of those charged with governance
questions.question: Those charged with governance are persons:

options.A: Responsible for the day-to-day management of the entity
options.B: Responsible for overseeing the strategic direction and accountability of the entity

questions.explanation: Those charged with governance have oversight responsibility for the entity's strategic direction and accountability, including overseeing the financial reporting process. This typically includes the board of directors or audit committee.
questions.tip: Governance = oversight role. Management = day-to-day operations. Different responsibilities.

questions.question: The auditor is required to communicate the auditor's responsibilities to governance, which includes:

options.A: Guaranteeing the accuracy of the financial statements
options.B: Forming and expressing an opinion on the financial statements
options.C: Detecting all fraud regardless of materiality
options.D: Managing the entity's internal control system

questions.explanation: The auditor communicates that their responsibility is to form and express an opinion on the financial statements, not to guarantee accuracy or detect all fraud. Management is responsible for the financial statements.
questions.tip: Auditor's responsibility = opinion. Management's responsibility = financial statements.

questions.question: Significant findings from the audit should be communicated to governance:

options.A: Only after the audit report is issued
options.B: On a timely basis, before the audit report is issued

questions.explanation: Significant audit matters should be communicated on a timely basis, enabling governance to take appropriate action before the audit report is issued. The timing depends on the significance of matters.
questions.tip: Timely communication = before report issuance. Governance needs info to act.

questions.question: Significant deficiencies and material weaknesses in internal control must be communicated to governance:

options.A: Orally only
options.B: In writing
options.C: Only if material to the financial statements

questions.explanation: Significant deficiencies and material weaknesses must be communicated to governance in writing. This written communication should be made no later than 60 days following the report release date.
questions.tip: SD and MW = written communication required. Can't just mention it orally.

questions.question: Communication of planned scope and timing of the audit helps governance:

options.A: Approve the audit fee
options.B: Better understand the audit approach and fulfill their oversight responsibilities
options.C: Direct the auditor's work to preferred areas
options.D: Reduce the extent of audit procedures

questions.explanation: Communicating planned scope and timing helps governance understand the auditor's approach, fulfill oversight responsibilities, and understand how the audit addresses risks. It facilitates effective two-way communication.
questions.tip: Scope/timing communication = helps governance with oversight, not to direct the audit.

questions.question: The auditor of an issuer must communicate to the audit committee:

options.A: Only impaired independence situations
options.B: All relationships with the entity that may bear on independence, in writing

questions.explanation: For issuers, the auditor must communicate in writing all relationships between the firm and the entity that may bear on independence, fees charged, and confirm independence or disclose any relationships that might be thought to bear on independence.
questions.tip: Issuers = written independence communication. All relationships, fees, and confirmation.

questions.question: The auditor should communicate to governance:

options.A: Only corrected misstatements
options.B: Uncorrected misstatements and the effect on the audit opinion
options.D: Misstatements only if management disagrees with them

questions.explanation: The auditor communicates all uncorrected misstatements accumulated during the audit, other than those deemed trivial, and their effect (individually and in aggregate) on the opinion. Governance may request correction.
questions.tip: Uncorrected misstatements = communicate to governance. They may push management to correct.

questions.question: The auditor should communicate fraud involving management to governance:

options.A: Only if it is material
options.B: Directly and on a timely basis, regardless of materiality

questions.explanation: Fraud involving management should be communicated directly to governance on a timely basis, regardless of the amount. Governance needs to know about management fraud to exercise oversight responsibility.
questions.tip: Management fraud = tell governance directly, regardless of materiality. It's a character issue.

questions.question: The auditor's communication about fraud risks should include discussion of:

options.A: Only confirmed fraud instances
options.B: The risk of management override of controls

questions.explanation: The auditor should discuss with governance the risk of management override of controls, which exists in all entities, and the auditor's procedures to address this risk. This helps governance understand a key audit focus area.
questions.tip: Management override = always a risk. Discuss with governance as part of fraud discussion.

questions.question: Audit communications with governance may be oral or written unless:

options.A: The entity is publicly traded
options.B: Specific matters are required by auditing standards to be in writing
options.D: The audit fee exceeds a certain threshold

questions.explanation: While many communications may be oral or written based on auditor judgment, certain matters must be communicated in writing, such as significant deficiencies and material weaknesses, and independence matters for issuers.
questions.tip: Some things must be written: SD/MW, independence (issuers). Others can be oral.

questions.question: Significant findings from the audit that should be communicated to governance include:

options.A: Only material misstatements that were corrected
options.B: Significant qualitative aspects of accounting practices, including policies and estimates
options.C: The auditor's detailed testing results for each account
options.D: Names of all audit team members

questions.explanation: Significant findings include qualitative aspects of accounting practices (significant policies, estimates, disclosures), significant difficulties encountered, disagreements with management, and other matters warranting governance attention.
questions.tip: Significant findings = accounting quality, difficulties, disagreements. Not detailed test results.

questions.question: Significant difficulties encountered during the audit that should be communicated include:

options.A: Staff turnover on the audit team
options.B: Significant delays in management providing information or unavailability of personnel

questions.explanation: Significant difficulties include management delays in providing information, unavailability of expected information, unwillingness to provide representations, or efforts to restrict audit scope. These may indicate broader issues.
questions.tip: Significant difficulties = management obstacles. May signal control or integrity concerns.

questions.question: For public companies, the appropriate governance body for audit communications is typically:

options.A: The CEO
options.B: The audit committee of the board of directors

questions.explanation: For public companies, the audit committee is typically the appropriate party to receive audit communications. The audit committee has direct oversight responsibility for the external audit and financial reporting.
questions.tip: Public company = communicate with audit committee. They oversee the audit.

questions.question: When all governance members are involved in management, the auditor:

options.A: Is exempt from governance communications
options.B: Should communicate matters to those persons in their governance role

questions.explanation: When governance members are also management, the auditor still communicates required matters but recognizes the individuals are being addressed in their governance capacity, not their management role.
questions.tip: Same people, different hats. Communicate matters relevant to their governance role.

questions.question: If the auditor identifies or suspects noncompliance with laws and regulations, communication to governance:

options.A: Is only required if the amounts are material
options.B: Should be made unless clearly inconsequential
options.C: Is prohibited due to attorney-client privilege
options.D: Should be made only to management first

questions.explanation: Unless matters are clearly inconsequential, the auditor should communicate identified or suspected noncompliance to governance. Management involvement in the noncompliance affects who receives the communication first.
questions.tip: Noncompliance = communicate to governance unless trivial. They need to know.

questions.question: Effective two-way communication between the auditor and governance involves:

options.A: The auditor only reporting findings at year-end
options.B: Both the auditor providing information and receiving input from governance

questions.explanation: Effective communication is two-way: the auditor provides information relevant to governance oversight, and governance provides information relevant to the audit, such as knowledge of matters that may affect the audit.
questions.tip: Two-way = auditor shares info, governance shares info. Not just one-way reporting.

questions.question: Significant related party transactions identified by the auditor should be communicated to governance because:

options.A: They are always fraudulent
options.B: Governance should evaluate whether they are properly accounted for and disclosed
options.C: They must be eliminated from the financial statements

questions.explanation: Related party transactions are communicated so governance can evaluate their business rationale, whether they are on arm's-length terms, and whether accounting and disclosure are appropriate. Governance oversight is important.
questions.tip: Related party = governance should evaluate. Business purpose and proper accounting.

questions.question: Disagreements between the auditor and management about accounting treatments:

options.A: Should remain confidential between auditor and management
options.B: Should be communicated to governance even if resolved
options.C: Only need to be communicated if unresolved

questions.explanation: Significant disagreements should be communicated to governance even if subsequently resolved. Governance should be aware of issues that arose during the audit and how they were resolved.
questions.tip: Disagreements = communicate even if resolved. Governance should know what was debated.

questions.question: If management seeks accounting advice from other accountants, the auditor should communicate to governance:

options.A: Nothing, as this is management's prerogative
options.B: The subject of the consultation and conclusions reached
options.C: Only if the advice differs from the auditor's view
options.D: Only the name of the other accountant

questions.explanation: When management consults with other accountants on significant matters, the auditor should communicate this to governance, including the subject and conclusions. This helps governance understand potentially sensitive areas.
questions.tip: Management seeking second opinion = governance should know about it and what was advised.

questions.question: When substantial doubt about going concern exists, the auditor should communicate to governance:

options.A: Only if the auditor modifies the opinion
options.B: The conditions giving rise to the doubt and management's plans
options.D: After the audit report is issued

questions.explanation: The auditor should communicate conditions and events that raise substantial doubt about going concern, the potential effects, and management's plans to address the conditions. Governance oversight is critical for such issues.
questions.tip: Going concern doubt = communicate conditions, effects, and management's response plans.

questions.question: Regarding significant accounting estimates, the auditor should communicate:

options.A: The exact amounts that should be recorded
options.B: The process used, significant assumptions, and management's judgment

questions.explanation: The auditor communicates management's process for making significant estimates, significant assumptions used, and any indicators of possible management bias. This helps governance oversee the subjectivity in financial reporting.
questions.tip: Estimates communication = process + assumptions + potential bias indicators.

questions.question: If the auditor identifies a material inconsistency between the financial statements and other information in the annual report:

options.A: This does not need to be communicated
options.B: The matter should be communicated to governance
options.C: The auditor should correct the annual report
options.D: Only legal counsel should be notified

questions.explanation: Material inconsistencies between audited financial statements and other information should be communicated to governance. If the financial statements are incorrect, they need revision; if other information is wrong, governance should address it.
questions.tip: Inconsistency with other information = tell governance so it can be resolved.

questions.question: Before issuing a modified audit opinion, the auditor should:

options.A: Obtain governance approval of the modification
options.B: Communicate the reasons and expected wording to governance

questions.explanation: The auditor should communicate to governance the circumstances resulting in expected modification and the proposed wording of the modification. This allows governance to respond before the report is issued.
questions.tip: No surprises. Communicate expected modifications and reasons before report issuance.

questions.question: Oral communications with governance should be:

options.A: Not documented
options.B: Documented in the audit work papers

questions.explanation: All significant communications with governance, whether oral or written, should be documented in the audit work papers. This includes what was communicated, when, and to whom.
questions.tip: Document all significant communicationsâ€”oral or written. Part of audit documentation.

questions.question: For issuers, the auditor must communicate to the audit committee:

options.A: Only the total audit fee
options.B: Total fees billed for audit and non-audit services during the period
options.C: Comparison of fees to industry benchmarks

questions.explanation: For issuers, the auditor must disclose in writing to the audit committee all fees billed for the period, broken down by category (audit fees, audit-related fees, tax fees, other fees), to help the committee assess independence.
questions.tip: Issuers = detailed fee disclosure by category. Helps audit committee assess independence.

questions.question: In a private company where governance is not clearly identified, the auditor should:

options.A: Assume management is governance
options.B: Agree with the entity on the relevant persons within the governance structure

questions.explanation: When the governance structure is not clearly defined, the auditor should discuss with management and agree on the appropriate persons to receive governance communications, considering who has oversight responsibility.
questions.tip: Unclear governance = discuss and agree on who should receive communications.

questions.question: A copy of the written management representation letter:

options.A: Must always be provided to governance
options.B: May be provided to governance if the auditor considers it appropriate
options.C: Should never be shared with governance
options.D: Must be approved by governance before signing

questions.explanation: While the representation letter is from management, the auditor may provide a copy to governance when appropriate. This can enhance governance awareness of matters management has confirmed to the auditor.
questions.tip: Rep letter to governance = optional but can be useful for their oversight.

questions.question: If the auditor becomes aware of a matter that is sensitive and governance itself may be involved:

options.A: The auditor should skip the communication
options.B: The auditor should consider communicating to an appropriate authority or seek legal advice
options.C: The matter should only be communicated to management

questions.explanation: When governance may be involved in sensitive matters (like fraud), the auditor considers alternative actions such as communicating to a higher level (board vs. committee) or seeking legal advice about responsibilities.
questions.tip: Governance involved = escalate within governance structure or get legal advice.

questions.question: Under PCAOB standards, before communicating critical audit matters in the audit report, the auditor should:

options.A: Obtain audit committee approval of the wording
options.B: Communicate the matters to the audit committee

questions.explanation: The PCAOB requires auditors to communicate to the audit committee which matters the auditor has determined to be critical audit matters before the CAMs are communicated in the audit report.
questions.tip: CAMs = communicate to audit committee before putting in the report. No surprises.

questions.question: A management letter containing recommendations is:

options.A: Required by auditing standards
options.B: A voluntary communication of matters the auditor believes are worthy of management's attention
options.D: Only issued when deficiencies are found

questions.explanation: A management letter is a voluntary by-product of the audit containing recommendations for improvements. It often includes operational or efficiency recommendations that don't rise to the level of required communications.
questions.tip: Management letter = voluntary recommendations. Not required but often expected.

questions.question: In a group audit, the group engagement team should communicate to group governance:

options.A: Only matters from the parent company audit
options.B: Matters from both parent and component audits that are relevant to group governance oversight
options.C: Detailed findings from each component auditor

questions.explanation: Group governance communications should include matters arising from both the parent audit and component audits that are relevant to group governance oversight, including an overview of the planned involvement with components.
questions.tip: Group governance = parent + component matters relevant to group oversight.

questions.question: Required written communications about internal control deficiencies should be made:

options.A: Within 30 days after report release
options.B: No later than 60 days following the report release date
options.C: Before the audit report is issued

questions.explanation: Written communication of significant deficiencies and material weaknesses should be made no later than 60 days following the report release date. Earlier communication is preferable to allow governance to respond.
questions.tip: 60 days from report release = deadline for SD/MW written communication.

questions.question: When governance has a designated subcommittee (such as an audit committee), the auditor should:

options.A: Always communicate with the full board
options.B: Communicate with the subcommittee unless matters should be communicated to the full governance body
options.C: Only communicate with the subcommittee chair
options.D: Choose randomly between the board and subcommittee

questions.explanation: When a subcommittee with relevant oversight responsibility exists, communications are typically made to that subcommittee. However, some matters may warrant full board communication depending on circumstances.
questions.tip: Subcommittee exists = communicate there unless matter requires full board attention.

questions.question: Holding private sessions with governance (without management present):

options.A: Is prohibited under auditing standards
options.B: May be appropriate to discuss sensitive matters or provide an opportunity for candid discussion
options.C: Is required for all public company audits
options.D: Should only occur if fraud is suspected

questions.explanation: Private sessions with governance allow candid discussion of sensitive matters that might be uncomfortable with management present, such as concerns about management's integrity or competence.
questions.tip: Private session = opportunity for candid discussion without management. Good practice.

questions.question: The engagement letter may be addressed to governance when:

options.A: Management requests it
options.B: Governance has authority to engage the auditor and set audit terms
options.C: The engagement is for a public company only
options.D: The prior year letter was also addressed to governance

questions.explanation: The engagement letter is typically addressed to the party with authority to engage the auditor. For many public companies, this is the audit committee, which has responsibility for appointing and overseeing the external auditor.
questions.tip: Engagement letter addressee = who has authority to engage auditor. Often audit committee.
